lines.text: It's bloody freezing!
Must be the weather, maam.
Should I serve sherry to the Spanish officers, sir?
Damn it, Stokeley, it's an execution, not a bloody christening.
You've had it easy in this war, Helene. Fluttering your eyelashes and living in Spanish splendour with your dear husband, the Marques.
I married him at Napoleon's request. I can't enjoy having him grunt all over me while I stole information for people like you.
I never considered it.
But then you've never had sex.
I've been speaking with some of the Spanish officers. The Marques is a very fine swordsman. He's been taking lessons in Paris from Ouellet!
Well, he can take lessons in Spain from me.
Good bye, Raoul. Come soon! (she leaves in a coach) But then again you always do.
If Sharpe is found not guilty the Spanish will never believe us or trust us again. They want justice.
I think they should get it, sir... whatever the verdict.
Major Sharpe, a gentleman you may not be but you will behave as one in this court! Do I make myself clear?
Your husband is dead, Marquesa.
I find it hard to tell the difference.
[after Sharpe is believed to be hanged]
Damn waste, Harper.
It was damn murder, sir.
Can I ask you where we're going, sir?
Over the hills, sergeant, and far away.
Right. Which hills and how far?
So you believe in ghosts, do you sergeant?
I believe in God the Father, God the Son and the sidhe ridin' the wind.
I hope you are well.
I hope you're in excruciating pain.
Father Hacha has told me of your deep desire to repent.
I haven't sinned enough yet.
[Sharpe and La Marquesa are escaping a monastery]
Stop!
Too late, sister. I'm off to commit adultery. Lots of it.
You saved my life.
You tried to end mine.
I've never met you.
Well, do you hear that, Pat? She's never met me.
You're bleeding, sir. Don't move.
What about my shameful suggestions?
What?
Oh, she's denying me now, Pat. After all we've been through.
I hear her, sir.
You think she'd remember the man who got down on his knees, drunk mind you, and crawled on her floor begging Her Ladyship to sleep with her. Bugger!
I'd remember it.
Aye! So would I. The man lost his honour because of the lady's lies. Stripped of his rank... hung on a rope.
Who are you?
You know who I am. My name is Sharpe.
Drunk again, Harper?
Oh, me too, sir.
You must count the ways of your death.
The dead don't count, El Matarife.
Bloody French on one side, partisans on the other... and we're stuck here with the woman who had me hung.
God does work in mysterious ways.
His name was Liam Dooley. He and his brother were going to be hanged for looting a church. I made them an offer. One could live, but one would die. Liam called heads. It was a very bad call.
You have failed me, priest.
I do not understand.
Sharpe is alive. The Marquesa is free. The English come.

[frightened]
Sharpe is dead. I saw him hanged.

[shoots Hacha]
You call me a liar?
He may already be dead.
You tried that one before, sir.
Did he interrogate her
[referring to the Marquesa]
He was at her all night.

[concerning the French]
We've got them running, Nairn! We're going to chase them out of Spain into France, and drown them in the Channel!

[the riflemen are telling jokes and laughing]
I got one for you! Where does Napoleon keep his armies?
I don't know, Perkins. Where does Napoleon keep his armies?
Up his sleevies!
[the riflemen laugh]

[discussing Sharpe's depression]
He needs a good battle.
He needs a good woman.
He had one, but he lost her. He went and lost her, so he did.
You make me feel...
...sixty again?
[both laugh]
Oh, you have a wicked tongue!
Do you have anything to say?
Permission to die in my rifleman's jacket, sir?
Denied.
Sarge? Where are we off to, Sarge?
We're going to join up with a man called Sharpe, lads.
You mean we're all gonna die?
You know the army boys, they couldn't hang a curtain!
You know the army boys, they couldn't hang a curtian!
